sample.dialogue: MOLL'S NURSE SPEAKS TO MOLL, WHO DOES NOT WANT TO GO INTO SERVICE. Thou foolish Child,
thou art always Crying;
prethee, What doest Cry for? because they will take me away,
and put me to Service, and I can't Work House-Work; well Child,
but tho' you can't Work House-Work, as you call it, you will learn it in time, and they won't put you to hard Things at first; yes they will,
and if I can't do it, they will Beat me, and the Maids will Beat me to make me do great Work, and I am but a little Girl, and I can't do it,
sample.nonSpeech: and then I cry'd again, till I could not speak any more to her.

dialogue.comment: THE NURSE PROMISES THAT MOLL WILL NOT GO INTO SERVICE UNTIL SHE IS OLDER.

sample.nonSpeech: WHEN she saw that I was not pacify'd yet, she began to be angry with me,
sample.dialogue: and what wou'd you have?
don't I tell you that you shall not go to Service till you are bigger? Ay,
but then I must go at last, why, what?
is the Girl mad? what, would you be a Gentlewoman? Yes
sample.nonSpeech:
says I , and cry'd heartily, till I roar'd out again.
THIS set the old Gentlewoman a Laughing at me, as you may be sure it would:
sample.dialogue: Well, Madam forsooth,
you would be a Gentlewoman, and pray how will you come to be a Gentlewoman? what, will you do it by your Fingers Ends? YES,
Why, what can you Earn,
what can you get at your Work? THREE-Pence,
when I Spin, and 4 d. when I Work plain Work. ALAS! poor Gentlewoman,
what will that do for thee? IT will keep me,
if you will let me live with you;
sample.nonSpeech: and this I said , in such a poor petitioning Tone, that it made the poor Womans Heart yearn to me, as she told me afterwards.
sample.dialogue: But,
that will not keep you, and buy you Cloths too; and who must buy the little Gentlewoman Cloths,
sample.nonSpeech: says she , and smil'd all the while at me.
sample.dialogue: I will Work Harder then,
and you shall have it all. POOR Child! it won't keep you,
it will hardly keep you in Victuals. THEN I will have no Victuals?
let me but live with you. WHY, can you live without Victuals?
yes,
sample.nonSpeech: again says I , very much like a Child, you may be sure, and still I cry'd heartily. I HAD no Policy in all this, you may easily see it was all Nature, but it was joyn'd with so much Innocence, and so much Passion, That in short, it set the good Motherly Creature a weeping too, and she cry'd at last as fast as I did, and then took me, and led me out of the teaching Room;
sample.dialogue: come
you shan't go to Service, you shall live with me,
sample.nonSpeech: and this pacify'd me for the present. SOMETIME after this, she going to wait on the Mayor , and talking of such things as belong'd to her Business, at last my Story came up, and my good Nurse told Mr. Mayor the whole Tale: He was so pleas'd with it, that he would call his Lady, and his two Daughters to hear it, and it made Mirth enough among them, you may be sure SOURCE TEXT: besure . HOWEVER, not a Week had pass'd over, but on a suddain comes Mrs. Mayoress , and her two Daughters to the House to see my old Nurse, and to see her School and the Children: When they had look'd about them a little:
sample.dialogue: Well, Mrs. ------
sample.nonSpeech: says the Mayoress to my Nurse;
sample.dialogue: and pray which is the little Lass that intends to be a Gentlewoman?
sample.nonSpeech: I heard, her and I was terrible frighted at first, tho' I did not know why neither; but Mrs. Mayoress comes up to me,
sample.dialogue: Well Miss
And what are you at Work upon?
sample.nonSpeech: The Word Miss was a Language that had hardly been heard of in our School, and I wondred what sad Name it was she call'd me; However, I stood up, made a Curtsy, and she took my Work out of my Hand, look'd on it, and said it was very well; then she took up one of my Hands,
sample.dialogue: nay,
the Child may come to be a Gentlewoman for ought any body knows, she has a Gentlewoman's Hand,

MOLL AND THE NURSE DISCUSS BEING A GENTLEWOMAN: MOLL MENTIONS A WOMAN WHO MENDS LACE AND IS CALLED "MADAM".
POOR Child,
you may soon be such a Gentlewoman as that, for she is a Person of ill Fame, and has had two or three Bastards.
sample.nonSpeech: I DID not understand any thing of that; but I answer'd,
sample.dialogue: I am sure they call her Madam, and she does not go to Service, nor do House-Work,
sample.nonSpeech: and therefore I insisted that she was a Gentlewoman, and I would be such a Gentlewoman as that.

dialogue.comment: MOLL WORKS IN A FAMILY, WHERE SHE IS COURTED BY THE ELDEST SON.

sample.nonSpeech: His Sisters would return softly to him,
sample.dialogue: Hush Brother, she will hear you, she is but in the next Room;
sample.nonSpeech: then he would put it off, and Talk softlier, as if he had not known it, and begun to acknowledge he was Wrong; and then as if he had forgot himself, he would speak aloud again, and I that was so well pleas'd to hear it, was sure to Lissen for it upon all Occasions. AFTER he had thus baited his Hook, and found easily enough the Method how to lay it in my Way, he play'd an opener Game; and one Day going by his Sister's Chamber when I was there, doing something about Dressing her, he comes in with an Air of gayty,
sample.dialogue: O! Mrs. Betty ,
How do you do Mrs. Betty ? don't your Cheeks burn, Mrs. Betty ?
sample.nonSpeech: I made a Curtsy, and blush'd, but said nothing;
sample.dialogue: What makes you talk so Brother,
Why,
we have been talking of her below Stairs this half Hour; Well
you can say no Harm of her, that I am sure, so 'tis no matter what you have been talking about; nay,

'tis so far from talking Harm of her, that we have been talking a great deal of good, and a great many fine Things have been said of Mrs. Betty , I assure you; and particularly, that she is the
Handsomest young Woman in Colchester ; and, in short, they begin to Toast her Health in the Town. I wonder at you Brother,

Betty wants but one Thing, but she had as good want every Thing, for the Market is against our Sex just now; and if a young Woman have Beauty, Birth, Breeding, Wit, Sense, Manners, Modesty, and all these to an Extream; yet if she have not Money, she's no Body, she had has good want them all, for nothing but Money now recommends a Woman; the Men play the Game all into their own Hands.
sample.nonSpeech: HER younger Brother, who was by, cry'd
sample.dialogue: Hold Sister , you run too fast, I am an Exception to your Rule; I assure you, if I find a Woman so Accomplish'd as you Talk of, I say , I assure you, I would not trouble myself about the Money. O ,
but you will take Care not to Fancy one then, without the Money. YOU don't know that neither,
BUT why Sister,
why do you exclaim so at the Men, for aiming so much at the Fortune? you are none of them that want a Fortune, what ever else you want. I understand you Brother,
you suppose I have the Money, and want the Beauty; but as Times go now, the first will do without the last, so I have the better of my Neighbours. WELL,

but your Neighbours, as you call them may be even with you for Beauty; will steal a Husband sometimes in spight of Money; and when the Maid chances to be Handsomer than the Mistress, she
oftentimes makes as good a Market, and rides in a Coach before her. MOLL LEAVES THE ROOM BUT SHE CAN HEAR THE CONVERSATION: SHE UNDERSTANDS THAT THE SISTER DISLIKES HER.
sample.nonSpeech: IT happen'd one Day that he came running up Stairs, towards the Room where his Sisters us'd to sit and Work, as he often us'd to do; and calling to them before he came in, as was his way too, I being there alone, step'd to the Door, and said,
as I step'd forward, to say this towards the Door, he was just got to the Door, and clasping me in his Arms, as if it had been by Chance,
sample.dialogue: O! Mrs. Betty ,
are you here? that's better still; I want to speak with you, more than I do with them,
sample.nonSpeech:
and then having me in his Arms he Kiss'd me three or four times. I struggl'd to get away, and yet did it but faintly neither, and he held me fast, and still
Kiss'd me, till he was almost out of Breath, and then sitting down, says,
sample.dialogue: dear Betty I am in Love with you.
sample.nonSpeech: HIS Words I must confess fir'd my Blood; all my Spirits flew about my Heart, and put me into Disorder enough, which he might easily have seen in my Face: He repeated it afterwards several times, that he was in Love with me, and my Heart spoke as plain as a Voice, that I lik'd it; nay, when ever he said,
sample.dialogue: I am in Love with you,
wou'd you were Sir.

dialogue.comment: MOLL HAS RECEIVED A NOTE FROM THE BROTHER ASKING HER TO GO INTO TOWN AND THAT HE WILL MEET HER ON THE WAY.

sample.nonSpeech: ACCORDINGLY after Dinner, he very gravely says to me, his Sisters being all by,
sample.dialogue: Mrs. Betty , I must ask a Favour of you: What's that?
nay, Sister
sample.nonSpeech: yes they said , they could spare her well enough, and the Sister beg'd Pardon for asking; which she did but of meer Course, without any Meaning;
sample.dialogue: Well, but Brother?
you must tell Mrs. Betty what it is; if it be any private Business, that we must not hear. You may call her out, there she is, why Sister,
What do you mean? I only desire her to go into the High-street ,
sample.nonSpeech: (and then he pulls out a Turn-Over)
sample.dialogue: to such a Shop,
sample.nonSpeech: and then he tells them a long Story of two fine Neckcloths he had bid Money for,

dialogue.comment: THE BROTHER LIES TO HIS FAMILY IN ORDER TO BE ABLE TO MEET WITH MOLL.

sample.nonSpeech: HE had scarse done speaking to them, and giving me my Errand, but his Man came up to tell him that Sir W--H--s Coach stop'd at the Door; so he runs down, and comes up again immediately,
sample.dialogue: alas!
there's all my Mirth spoil'd at once; Sir W-- has sent his Coach for me, and desires to speak with me upon some earnest Business: MOLL AND THE BROTHER MEET.
sample.nonSpeech: HOWEVER as he press'd me to speak, I told him, I had no Reason to question the Sincerity of his Love to me, after so many Protestations, But -- and there I stopp'd, as if I left him to Guess the rest;
sample.dialogue: BUT WHAT my Dear?
I guess what you mean; what if you should be with Child, is not that it? Why then,
I'll take Care of you, and Provide for you, and the Child too, and that you may see I am not in Jest,
here's an Earnest for you;
and I'll give you such another,
every Year till I Marry you.
THE YOUNGER BROTHER BEGINS TO COURT MOLL, WHICH COMES TO THE ATTENTION OF THE REST OF THE FAMILY: MOLL IS AFRAID SHE WILL BE THROWN OUT AND TELLS THE ELDER BROTHER. WHY look you Child,

that they are Uneasie about you, that is true; but that they have the least Suspicion of the Case as it is, and as it respects you and I, is so far from bring True, that they suspect my Brother Robin ; and in short, they are fully persuaded he makes Love to you: Nay, the Fool has put it into their Heads too himself, for he is continually Bantring them about it, and making a Jest of himself; I confess, I think he is wrong to do so, because he can not but see it vexes them, and makes them Unkind to you; but 'tis a Satisfaction to me, because of the Assurance it gives me, that they do not suspect me in the least, and I hope this will be to your Satisfaction too. SO it is,
one way, but this does not reach my Case at all, nor is this the chief Thing that Troubles me, tho' I have been concern'd about that too: What is it then,

dialogue.comment: MOLL TELLS THE ELDER BROTHER ABOUT THE YOUNGER BROTHER'S COURTING HER.

sample.nonSpeech: I told him how far I had resisted him, and told him how Sincere and Honourable his Offers were,
sample.dialogue: but

my Case will be doubly hard; for as they carry it Ill to me now, because he desires to have me, they'll carry it worse when they shall find I have Deny'd him; and they will presently say, there's something else in it, and then out it comes, that I am Marry'd already to somebody else, or else that I would never refuse a Match so much above me as this was. MOLL AND THE ELDER BROTHER CONTINUE.
WELL my Dear

don't be Concern'd at that now, if I am not your Husband, I'll be as good as a Husband to you, and do not let those things Trouble you now, but let me look a little farther into this Affair, and I shall be able to say more next time we meet. MOLL REPEATS THE DISCOURSE BETWEEN THE TWO BROTHERS.
sample.nonSpeech: He told him he heard strange News of him since he went, ( viz. ) that he made Love to Mrs. Betty :
sample.dialogue: Well,
sample.nonSpeech: says his Brother, a little Angrily,
sample.dialogue: and so I do , And what then? What has any body to do with that? Nay,

don't be Angry Robin , I don't pretend to have any thing to do with it; nor do I pretend to be Angry with you about it: But I find they do concern themselves about it, and that they have used the poor Girl Ill about it, which I should take as done to my self; Who do you mean by THEY?
I mean my Mother, and the Girls,
BUT hark ye,
are you in Earnest, do you really Love the Girl, you may be free with me you know? Why then
I will be free with you, I do Love her above all the Women in the World, and I will have Her, let them say , and do what they will, I believe the Girl will not Deny me.
sample.nonSpeech: IT stuck me to the Heart when he told me this, for tho' it was most rational to think I would not Deny him, yet I knew in my own Conscience, I must Deny him, and I saw my Ruin in my being oblig'd to do so; but I knew it was my business to Talk otherwise then, so I interrupted him in his Story thus.
sample.dialogue: AY!
does he think I can not Deny him? but he shall find I can Deny him, for all that. WELL my dear
but let me give you the whole Story as it went on between us, and then say what you will.
sample.nonSpeech: THEN he went on and told me , that he reply'd thus:
sample.dialogue: But Brother, you know She has nothing, and you may have several Ladies with good Fortunes: 'Tis no matter for that,
I Love the Girl; and I will never please my Pocket in Marrying, and not please my Fancy; and so my Dear
there is no Opposing him. YES, yes,

you shall see I can Oppose him, I have learnt to say NO now, tho' I had not learnt it before; if the best Lord in the Land offer'd me Marriage now, I could very chearfully say NO to him. WELL, but my Dear

What can you say to him? You know, as you said when we talk'd of it before, he will ask you many Questions about it, and all the House will wonder what the meaning of it should be.
WHY
I can stop all their Mouths at one Clap, by telling him and them too, that I am Married already to his elder Brother.
sample.nonSpeech: HE smil'd a little too at the Word, but I could see it Startled him, and he could not hide the disorder it put him into; however, he return'd,
sample.dialogue: Why tho' that may be true in some Sense, yet I suppose you are but in Jest, when you talk of giving such an Answer as that, it may not be Convenient on many Accounts. NO, no
I am not so fond of letting that Secret come out, without your Consent. BUT what then can you say to him, or to them,
when they find you positive against a Match, which would be apparently so much to your Advantage? WHY,

should I be at a loss? First of all, I am not oblig'd to give them any Reason at all, on the other hand, I may tell them, I am Married already, and stop there, and that will be a full Stop too to him, for he can have no Reason to ask one Question after it. AY,
but the whole House will teize you about that, even to Father and Mother, and if you deny them positively, they will be Disoblig'd at you, and Suspicious besides. WHY,

What can I do? What would you have me do? I was in strait enough before, and as I told you , I was in Perplexity before, and acquainted you with the Circumstances, that I might have your Advice. MY dear

I have been considering very much upon it, you may be sure, and tho' it is a piece of Advice, that has a great many Mortifications in it to me, and may at first seem Strange to you, yet all Things consider'd, I see no better
way for you, than to let him go on; and if you find him hearty and in Earnest, Marry him.
sample.nonSpeech: I gave him a look full of Horror at those Words, and turning Pale as Death, was at the very point of sinking down out of the Chair I sat in: When giving a start,
sample.dialogue: my Dear,
What's the matter with you? Where are you a going?
sample.nonSpeech: and a great many such things; and with joging and calling to me, fetch'd me a little to my self, tho' it was a good while before I fully recover'd my Senses, and was not able to speak for several Minutes more. WHEN I was fully recover'd he began again;
sample.dialogue: My dear

What made you so Surpriz'd at what I said, I would have you consider Seriously of it? you may see plainly how the Family stand in this Case, and they would be stark Mad if it was my Case, as it is my Brothers, and for I ought I see, it would be my Ruin and yours too. AY!

are all your Protestations and Vows to be shaken by the dislike of the Family? Did I not always object that to you, and you made a light thing of it, as what you were above, and would not Value; and is it come to this now?
is this your Faith and Honour, your Love, and the Solidity of your Promises?
sample.nonSpeech: HE continued perfectly Calm, notwithstanding all my Reproaches, and I was not sparing of them at all; but he reply'd at last,
sample.dialogue:
My Dear, I have not broken one Promise with you yet; I did tell you I would Marry you when I was come to my Estate; but you see my Father is a hail healthy Man, and may live these thirty Years still, and not be Older than several are round us in the Town; and you never propos'd my Marrying you
sooner, because you know it might be my Ruin, and as to all the rest, I have not fail'd you in any thing, you have wanted for nothing.
sample.nonSpeech: I could not deny a Word of this, and had nothing to say to it in general;
sample.dialogue: but why then,

can you perswade me to such a horrid stop, as leaving you, since you have not left me? Will you allow no Affection, no Love on my Side, where there has been so much on your Side? Have I made you no Returns? Have I given no Testimony of my Sincerity, and of my Passion? are the Sacrifices I have made of Honour and Modesty to you, no Proof of my being ty'd to you in Bonds too strong to be broken? BUT here my Dear,

you may come into a safe Station, and appear with Honour, and with splendor at once, and the Remembrance of what we have done, may be wrapt up in an eternal Silence, as if it had never happen'd; you shall always have my Respect, and my sincere Affection, only then it shall be Honest, and perfectly Just to my Brother, you shall be my Dear Sister, as now you are my Dear --
YOUR Dear whore,

you would have said, if you had gone on; and you might as well have said it; but I understand you: However, I desire you to remember the long Discourses you have had with me, and the many Hours pains you have taken to perswade me to believe myself an honest Woman; that I was your Wife intentionally, tho' not in the Eye of the World; and that it was as effectual a Marriage that had pass'd between us, as if we had been publickly Wedded by the Parson of the Parish; you know and cannot but remember, that these have been your own Words to me.
sample.nonSpeech: I found this was a little too close upon him, but I made it up in what follows; he stood stock still for a while, and said nothing, and I went on thus;
sample.dialogue: you cannot,

without the highest injustice believe that I yielded upon all these Perswasions without a Love not to be questioned, not to be shaken again by any thing that could happen afterward: If you have such dishonourable Thoughts of me, I must ask you what Foundation in any of my Behaviour have I given for such a Suggestion. IF than I have yielded to the Importunities of my Affection; and if I have been perswaded to believe that I am really, and in the Essence of the Thing your Wife, shall I now give the Lye to all those Arguments, and call myself your Whore, or Mistress, which is the same thing? And will you Transfer me to your Brother? Can you Transfer my Affection? Can you bid me cease loving you, and bid me love him? is it in my Power think you to make such a Change at Demand? No Sir,

depend upon it 'tis impossible, and whatever the Change of your Side may be, I will ever be True; and I had much rather, since it is come that unhappy Length, be your Whore than your Brothers Wife. THE ELDER BROTHER ASKS MOLL IF SHE IS PREGNANT.
sample.nonSpeech: I guess'd at his Question presently, namely, Whether I was sure I was not with Child? As to that, I told him , he need not be concern'd about it, for I was not with Child;
sample.dialogue: why then my Dear,
MOLL HAS BEEN ILL FOR FIVE WEEKS: THE DOCTORS SUSPECT IT IS BECAUSE SHE IS IN LOVE, WHICH IS DISCUSSED BY THE FAMILY. ALAS,
that poor Girl; I am afraid she will never be well. WELL!
How should Mrs. Betty be well, they say she is in Love? I believe nothing of it
I don't know

what to say to it, they have made such a rout about her being so Handsome, and so Charming, and I know not what, and that in her hearing too, that has turn'd the Creatures Head I believe, and who knows what possessions may follow such Doings? for my Part I don't know what to make of it. WHY Sister, you must acknowledge she is very Handsome,
AY, and a great deal Handsomer than you Sister,
and that's your Mortification. WELL, well, that is not the Question,
the Girl is well enough, and she knows it well enough; she need not be told of it to make her Vain. WE are not a talking of her being Vain,

but of her being in Love; it may be she is in Love with herself, it seems my Sisters think so.
I would she was in Love with me,
I'd quickly put her out of her Pain. WHAT d'ye mean by that Son,
How can you talk so? WHY Madam,
Do you think I'd let the poor Girl Die for Love, and of one that is near at hand to be had too. FYE Brother,
how can you talk so? would you take a Creature that has not a Groat in the World? PRETHEE Child
Beauties a Portion, and good Humour with it, is a double Portion; I wish thou hadst half her Stock of both for thy Portion:
sample.nonSpeech: So there was her Mouth stopp'd.
sample.dialogue: I find,
if Betty is not in Love, my Brother is; I wonder he has not broke his Mind to Betty , I warrant she won't say NO. THEY that yield when they're ask'd

are one step before them that were never ask'd to yield, Sister, and two Steps before them that yield before they are ask'd: And that's an Answer to you Sister. THE FAMILY'S DISCUSSION CONTINUES.
She's wrong there,
for if there was not a great deal between us, we should be closer together than we are: I told her I Lov'd her hugely,
but I could never make the Jade believe I was in Earnest; I do not know how you should
no body in their Senses could believe you were in Earnest, to Talk so to a poor Girl, whose Circumstances you know so well. BUT prethee Son

since you tell me that you could not make her believe you were in Earnest, what must we believe about it? for you ramble so in your Discourse, that no body knows whether you are in Earnest or in Jest: But as I find the Girl by your own Confession has answer'd truely, I wish you would do so too, and tell me
seriously, so that I may depend upon it; Is there any thing in it or no? Are you in Earnest or no? Are you Distracted indeed, or are you not? 'Tis a weighty Question, and I wish you would make us easie about it. BY my Faith Madam,

'tis in vain to mince the Matter, or tell any more Lyes about it, I am in Earnest, as much as a Man is, that's going to be Hang'd. If Mrs. Betty would say she Lov'd me, and that she would Marry me, I'd have her to morrow Morning fasting; and say, To have, and to hold , instead of eating my Breakfast. WELL,
then there's one Son lost; and she said it in a very mournful Tone, as one greatly concern'd at it. I hope not Madam,
no Man is lost, when a good Wife has found him. WHY but Child,
she is a Beggar. WHY then Madam, she has the more need of Charity
I'll take her off of the hands of the Parish, and she and I'll Beg together. ITS bad Jesting with such things,
I don't Jest Madam,
We'll come and beg your Pardon Madam; and your Blessing Madam, and my Fathers. THIS is all out of the way Son,
if you are in Earnest you are Undone. I am afraid not

for I am really afraid she won't have me, after all my Sisters huffing and blustring; I believe I shall never be able to persuade her to it. THAT'S a fine Tale indeed, she is not so far out of her Senses neither; Mrs. Betty is no Fool,
Do you think she has learnt to say NO, any more than other People? NO Mrs. Mirth-Wit
Mrs. Betty's no Fool; but Mrs. Betty may be Engag'd some other way, And what then? NAY,
we can say nothing to that, Who must it be to then? She is never out of the Doors, it must be between you. I have nothing to say to that
I have been Examin'd enough; there's my Brother, if it must be between us , go to Work with him.
sample.nonSpeech: THIS stung the elder Brother to the Quick, and he concluded that Robin had discover'd something: However, he kept himself from appearing disturb'd;
sample.dialogue: Prethee
don't go to sham your Stories off upon me, I tell you, I deal in no such Ware; I have nothing to say to Mrs. Betty , nor to any of the Miss Betty's in the Parish;
sample.nonSpeech: and with that he rose up and brush'd off.
sample.dialogue: NO,
I dare answer for my Brother, he knows the World better.
sample.nonSpeech: THUS the Discourse ended; but it left the elder Brother quite confounded: He concluded his Brother had made a full Discovery, and he began to doubt, whether I had been concern'd in it, or not; but with all his Management, he could not bring it about to get at me; at last, he was so perplex'd, that he was quite Desperate, and resolv'd he wou'd come into my Chamber and see me, whatever came of it: In order to this, he contriv'd it so; that one Day after Dinner, watching his eldest Sister , till he could see her go up Stairs, he runs after her,
sample.dialogue: Hark ye Sister ,
Where is this sick Woman? may not a body see her? YES,
I believe you may, but let me go first a little, and I'll tell you;
sample.nonSpeech:
so she
run up to the Door, and gave me notice; and presently call'd to him again:
sample.dialogue: BROTHER,
you may come if you please;
sample.nonSpeech: so in he came, just in the same kind of Rant:
sample.dialogue: Well,
sample.nonSpeech: says he , at the Door as he came in ,
sample.dialogue: Where is this sick Body that's in Love? How do ye do Mrs. Betty ?
sample.nonSpeech: I would have got up out of my Chair, but I was so Weak I could not for a good while; and he saw it and his Sister too, and she said,
sample.dialogue: Come do not strive to stand up , my Brother desires no Ceremony, especially, now you are so Weak. NO, NO, Mrs. Betty , pray sit still
sample.nonSpeech: says he , and so sits himself down in a Chair over-against me, and appear'd as if he was mighty Merry. sample.dialogue: Poor Mrs. Betty ,
it is a sad thing to be in Love, why it has reduced you sadly;
sample.nonSpeech: at last I spoke a little,
sample.dialogue: I am glad to see you so Merry: Sir

but I think the Doctor might have found some thing better to do, than to make his Game at his Patients: If I had been Ill of no other Distemper, I know the Proverb too well to have let him come to me: What Proverb
O! I remember it now: What, Where Love is the Case, The Doctor's an Ass. IS not that it Mrs. Betty ?
Nay,

I think the effect has prov'd it to be Love; for it seems the Doctor has been able to do you but little Service, you mend very slowly they say, I doubt there's somewhat in it
Mrs. Betty , I doubt you are Sick of the Incureables, and that is Love;
No, indeed Sir , that's none of my Distemper.

sample.dialogue: No, it would not hurt me: And pray Madam,
do not hinder it, I love the Musick of the Flute very much;
well do then Brother;
sample.nonSpeech: with that he pull'd out the Key of his Closet,
sample.dialogue: Dear Sister,
I am very Lazy, do step to my Closet and fetch my Flute, it lies in such a Drawer ,

sample.dialogue: MOLL HAS MARRIED. MY DEAR,
we have been married a Fortnight, is it not time to let you know whether you have got a Wife with something, or with nothing; your own time for that, my Dear,
I am satisfied that I have got the Wife I love, I have not troubled you much,
with my enquiry after it. THAT'S true,
but I have a great difficulty upon me about it, which I scarce know how to manage. WHAT'S that, my Dear,
WHY,
'tis a little hard upon me, and 'tis harder upon you; I am told that Captain --
has told you I had a great deal more Money than I ever pretended to have, and I am sure I never employ'd him to do so. WELL,

Captain -- may have told me so, but what then, if you have not so much that may lye at his Door, but you never told me what you had, so I have no reason to blame you if you have nothing at all.
THAT is so just,
and so generous, that it makes my having but a little a double Affliction to me. THE less you have, my Dear ,

the worse for us both; but I hope your Affliction you speak of, is not caus'd for fear I should be unkind to you, for want of a Portion, NO NO, if you have nothing to tell me plainly, and at once; I may perhaps tell the Captain he has cheated me, but I can never say you have cheated me, for did you not give it under your Hand that you were Poor, and so I ought to expect you to be. WELL,
my Dear , I am glad I have not been concern'd in deceiving you before Marriage, if I deceive you since, 'tis ne'er the worse; that I am Poor is too true, but not so Poor as to have nothing neither;
sample.nonSpeech: so I pull'd out some Bank Bills, and gave him about a Hundred and Sixty Pounds,
sample.dialogue: there's something, my Dear,

and not quite all neither. MOLL BRINGS MORE MONEY TO HER HUSBAND.
And now, MY DEAR,
sample.nonSpeech: I added, that if the Person who had my 600 l. had not abus'd me, I had been worth a Thousand Pound to him, but that as it was, I had been faithful to him, and reserv'd nothing to my self, but if it had been more he should have had it.

dialogue.comment: MOLL AND HER HUSBAND HAVE MOVED TO HIS ESTATE IN VIRGINIA: SHE SPEAKS WITH HER MOTHER-IN-LAW.

sample.nonSpeech: AMONG the rest, she often told me how the greatest part of the Inhabitants of the Colony came thither in very indifferent Circumstances from England ; that, generally speaking, they were of two sorts, either (1.) such as were brought over by Masters of Ships to be sold as Servants,
sample.dialogue: such as we call them , my Dear,
but they are more properly call'd Slaves .
sample.nonSpeech:
Or, (2.) Such as are Transported from Newgate and other Prisons,
after having been found guilty of Felony and other Crimes punishable, with Death.
sample.dialogue: WHEN they come here,
we make no difference, the Planters buy them, and they work together in the Field till their time is out; when 'tis expir'd,

they have Encouragement given them to Plant for themselves; for they have a certain number of Acres of Land allotted them by the Country, and they go to work to Clear and Cure the Land, and then to Plant it with Tobacco and Corn for their own use; and as the Tradesmen and Merchants will trust them with Tools, and Cloaths, and other Necessaries, upon the Credit of their Crop before it is grown, so they again Plant every Year a little more than the Year before, and so buy whatever they want with the Crop that is before them. HENCE Child,
many a Newgate Bird becomes a great Man, and we have,
several Justices of the Peace, Officers of the Train Bands, and Magistrates of the Towns they live in, that have been burnt in the Hand.
sample.nonSpeech: SHE was going on with that part of the Story, when her own part in it interrupted her, and with a great deal of good-humour'd Confidence she told me, she was one of the second sort of Inhabitants herself; that she came away openly, having ventur'd too far in a particular Case, so that she was become a Criminal,
sample.dialogue: and here's the Mark of it, CHILD,
sample.nonSpeech: says she , and pulling of her Glove,
sample.dialogue: look ye here,
sample.nonSpeech: says she , turning up the Palm of her Hand, and shewed me a very fine white Arm and Hand, but branded in the inside of the Hand, as in such cases it must be. THIS Story was very moving to me, but my Mother (smiling said,
sample.dialogue:
you need not think such a
thing strange, Daughter , for as I told you, some of the best Men in this Country are burnt in the Hand, and they are not asham'd to own it; there's Major --
he was an Eminent Pick-pocket; there's Justice Ba--r was a Shoplifter, and both of them were burnt in the Hand, and I could name you several, such as they are. MOLL AND HER MOTHER-IN-LAW CONTINUE.
sample.nonSpeech: HERE my Mother-in-Law ran out in a long account of the wicked practices in that dreadful Place, and how it ruin'd more young People than all the Town besides;
sample.dialogue: and Child,
perhaps you may know little of it, or it may be have heard nothing about it, but depend upon it,
we all know here, that there are more Thieves and Rogues made by that one Prison of Newgate , than by all the Clubs and Societies of Villains in the Nation; 'tis that cursed Place,

that half Peoples this Colony. MOLL SUDDENLY REALISES THAT HER MOTHER-IN-LAW IS HER OWN MOTHER AND THUS MOLL'S HUSBAND IS HER BROTHER. HOWEVER MOLL PRETENDS SHE IS UPSET BECAUSE OF HER MOTHER'S SAD STORY.
Why , my Dear,

what need these things trouble you? These Passages were long before your time, and they give me no trouble at all now, nay I look back on them with a particular Satisfaction, as they have been a means to bring me to this place?
but come, my Dear ,
what Conditions will you make with me upon the opening this Affair to you. ANY Conditions in the World,
that you can in reason desire of me; well,

come, give it me under your Hand, that if you do not find I am in any fault, or that I am willingly concern'd in the Causes of the Misfortune that is to follow, you will not blame me, use me the worse, do me any Injury, or make me be the Sufferer for that which is not my fault. THAT,

is the most reasonable demand in the World; not to blame you for that which is
not your fault; give me a Pen and Ink,
sample.nonSpeech: says he , so I ran in and fetch'd a Pen, Ink, and Paper, and he wrote the Condition down in the very words I had proposed it, and sign'd it with his Name;
sample.dialogue: well,
what is next , my Dear? WHY,
the next is, that you will not blame me for not discovering the Secret of it to you before I knew it. VERY just again,

then I have but one Condition more to make with you, and that is, that as there is no body concern'd in it but you and I, you shall not discover it to any Person in the World, except your own Mother; and that in all the Measures you shall take upon the discovery, as I am equally concern'd in it with you, tho' as innocent as your self , you shall do nothing in a Passion, nothing to my Prejudice, or to your Mother's Prejudice, without my knowledge and consent.
sample.nonSpeech: THIS a little amaz'd him, and he wrote down the words distinctly, but read them over and over before he Sign'd them, hesitating at them several times, and repeating them;
sample.dialogue: my Mother's Prejudice! and your Prejudice ! what mysterious thing can this be?
sample.nonSpeech: however, at last he Sign'd it.
sample.dialogue: WELL,

my Dear, I'll ask you no more under your Hand, but as you are to bear the most unexpected and surprizing thing that perhaps ever befel any Family in the World, I beg you to promise me you will receive it with Composure and a Presence of Mind suitable to a Man of Sense. I'LL do my utmost,

upon Condition you will keep me no longer in suspence, for you Terrify me with all these Preliminaries.
WELL then,

it is this, as I told you before in a Heat, that I was not your lawful Wife, and that our Children were not legal Children; so I must let you know now in calmness, and in kindness, but with Affliction enough that I am your own Sister, and you my own Brother, and that we are both the Children of our Mother now alive, and in the House, who is convinc'd of the Truth of it, in a manner not to be denied or contradicted.
sample.nonSpeech: I SAW him turn pale, and look wild, and I said,
sample.dialogue: now remember your Promise, and receive it with Presence of mind; for who cou'd have said more to prepare you for it, than I have done?
sample.nonSpeech: However I call'd a Servant, and got him a little Glass of Rum, which is the usual Dram of the Country, for he was just fainting away. WHEN he was a little recover'd, I said to him ,
sample.dialogue: this Story you may be sure requires a long Explanation, and therefore have patience and compose your Mind to hear it out, and I'll make it as short as I can,
sample.nonSpeech: and with this, I told him what I thought was needful of the Fact, and particularly how my Mother came to discover it to me, as above;
sample.dialogue: and now my Dear,
you will see Reason for my Capitulations, and that I neither have been the Cause of this Matter, nor could be so, and that I could know nothing of it before now. I AM fully satisfy'd of that,
but 'tis a dreadful Surprize to me; however, I know a Remedy for it all, and a Remedy that shall put an End to all your Difficulties, without your going to England ; That would be strange,
as all the rest; No, No,

I'll make it easie, there's no Body in the way of it all, but
myself:

dialogue.comment: A MIDWIFE COMES TO SEE MOLL, WHO HAS RETURNED TO ENGLAND.

sample.nonSpeech: My Landlady had told her I was very Melancholy, and that she believ'd that had done me harm; and once, before me , said to her,
sample.dialogue: Mrs. B --
I believe this Lady's Trouble is of a kind that is pretty much in your way, and therefore if you can do any thing for her, pray do, for she is a very civil Gentlewoman,
sample.nonSpeech: and so she went out of the Room. I REALLY did not understand her, but my Mother Midnight began very seriously to explain what she meant, as soon as she was gone:
sample.dialogue: Madam,

you seem not to understand what your Landlady means, and when you do understand it, you need not let her know at all that you do so.
SHE means that you are under some Circumstances that may render your Lying-Inn difficult to you, and that you are not willing to be expos'd; I need say no more, but to tell you, that if you think fit to communicate so much of your Case to me, if it be so , as is necessary; for I do not desire to pry into those things, I perhaps may be in a Condition to assist you, and to make you perfectly easie, and remove all your dull Thoughts upon that Subject. MOLL TELLS PART OF HER STORY TO THE MIDWIFE.
every Woman,
that is with Child has a Father for it,
sample.nonSpeech: and whether that Father was a Husband or no Husband, was no Business of hers; her Business was to assist me in my present Circumstances, whether I had a Husband or no;
sample.dialogue: for, Madam ,

to have a Husband that cannot appear, is to
have no Husband in the sense of the Case, and therefore whether you are a Wife or a Mistress is all one to me.
sample.nonSpeech: I FOUND presently, that whether I was a Whore or a Wife, I was to pass for a Whore here, so I let that go; I told her , it was true as she said, but that however, if I must tell her my Case, I must tell it her as it was: So I related it to her as short as I could, and I concluded it to her thus,
sample.dialogue: I trouble you with all this , Madam,

not that, as you said before, it is much to the purpose in your Affair, but this is to the purpose, namely, that I am not in any pain about being seen, or being publick or conceal'd, for 'tis perfectly indifferent to me; but my difficulty is, that I have no Acquaintance in this part of the Nation . I UNDERSTAND you, Madam,
you have no Security to bring to prevent the Parish Impertinences usual in such Cases; and perhaps,
do not know very well how to dispose of the Child when it comes; the last,
is not so much my concern as the first: Well, Madam,
dare you put your self into my Hands, I live in such a place, tho' I do not enquire after you, you may enquire after me, my Name is B-- I live in such a Street,

at the Sign of the Cradle , my Profession is a Midwife, and I have many Ladies that come to my House to Lye-Inn; I have given Security to the Parish in General Terms to secure them from any Charge, from whatsoever shall come into the World under my Roof; I have but one Question to ask in the whole Affair, Madam,
and if that be answer'd, you shall be entirely easie for all the rest.
sample.nonSpeech: I presently understood what she meant, and told her,
sample.dialogue: Madam, I believe I understand you ; I thank God, tho' I want Friends in this Part of the World, I do not want Money, so far as may be Necessary, tho' I do not abound in that neither :
sample.nonSpeech: This I added, because I would not make her expect great things;
sample.dialogue: well Madam,
that is the thing indeed, without which nothing can be done in these Cases; and yet,

you shall see that I will not impose upon you, or offer any thing that is unkind to you, and if you desire it, you shall know every thing before hand, that you may suit your self to the Occasion, and be either costly or sparing as you see fit. MOLL RECEIVES A BILL OF FARE FOR THE MIDWIFE'S SERVICES.
sample.nonSpeech: SHE told me , I should be Judge of that, when I saw them: I told her , I was sorry to tell her that I fear'd I must be her lowest rated Customer, and
sample.dialogue: perhaps Madam ,
you will make me the less Welcome upon that Account . No not at all,

for where I have One of the third Sort, I have Two of the Second, and Four to One of the First, and I get as much by them in Proportion, as by any; but if you doubt my Care of you, I will allow any Friend you have to overlook, and see if you are well waited on, or no.
sample.nonSpeech: THEN she explain'd the particulars of her Bill;
sample.dialogue: in the first Place, Madam,
I would have you Observe, that here is three Months Keeping, you are but 10 s. a Week, I undertake to say you will not complain of my Table: I suppose,
you do not live Cheaper where you are now; no indeed,

nor so Cheap, for I give six Shillings per Week for my Chamber, and find my own Diet as well as I can, which costs me a great deal more.
THEN Madam,

If the Child should not live, or should be dead Born, as you know sometime happens, then there is the Minister's Article saved; and if you have no Friends to come to you, you may save the Expence of a Supper; so that take those Articles out Madam,

your Lying-In will not cost you above 5 l. 3 s. in all, more than your ordinary Charge of Living. MOLL AGREES TO THE TERMS, AND HOPES THE "WOMAN OF THE HOUSE" WILL NOT THINK BADLY OF HER.
O DEAR,

her Ladyship is no stranger to these things; she has try'd to entertain Ladies in your Condition several times, but could not secure the Parish; and besides, she is not such a nice Lady as you take her to be; however, since you are agoing you shall not meddle with her, but I'll see you are a little better look'd after while you are here, than I think you are, and it shall not cost you the more neither.

dialogue.comment: MOLL SPEAKS TO HER "GOVERNESS", WHOM SHE CALLS MOTHER.

sample.nonSpeech: I told her I own'd she had.
sample.dialogue: Well my Dear,

and when you are gone, what are you to me? and what would it be to me if you were to be Hang'd? Do you think there are not Women, who as it is their Trade, and they get their Bread by it,
value themselves upon their being as careful of Children, as their own Mothers can be, and understand it rather better? Yes, yes, Child,
fear it not, How were we Nurs'd ourselves? Are you sure, you was Nurs'd up by your own Mother? and yet you look fat, and fair Child,
never be concern'd Child,
sample.nonSpeech: says she , going on in her drolling way;
sample.dialogue: I have no Murtherers about me, I employ the best, and the honestest Nurses that can be had; and have as few Children miscarry under their Hands, as there would, if they were all Nurs'd by Mothers; we want neither Care or Skill. MOLL AND HER GOVERNESS CONTINUE. IT may be true Mother,

for ought I know, but my Doubts are very strongly
grounded, indeed; come then,
lets hear some of them: Why first,
you give a Piece of Money to these People to take the Child off the Parents Hands, and to take Care of it as long as it lives; now we know Mother,

that those are poor People, and their Gain consists in being quit of the Charge as soon as they can; how can I doubt but that, as it is best for them to have the Child die, they are not over Solicitous about its Life. THIS is all Vapours and Fancy,
I tell you their Credit depends upon the Child's Life, and they are as careful as any Mother of you all. O Mother,

if I was but sure my little Baby would be carefully look'd to, and have Justice done it, I should be happy indeed; but it is impossible I can be satisfy'd in that Point, unless I saw it, and to see it, would be Ruin and Destruction to me, as now my Case stands, so what to do I know not. A FINE Story!

you would see the Child, and you would not see the Child; you would be Conceal'd and Discover'd both together; these are things impossible my Dear, so you must e'n do as other conscientious Mothers have done before you; and be contented with things as they must be, tho' they are not as you wish them to be. MOLL AND THE GOVERNESS CONTINUE.
sample.nonSpeech: AT last my old Governness came to me, with her usual Assurance.
sample.dialogue: Come my Dear,
I have found out a way how you shall be at a certainty, that your Child shall be used well, and yet the People that take Care of it shall never know you, or who the Mother of the Child is. O Mother,
sample.nonSpeech: says I SOURCE TEXT HAS she FOR I ,
sample.dialogue: If you can do so, you will engage me to you for ever: Well,
are you willing to be at some small Annual Expence, more than what we usually give to the People we Contract with? Ay,
with all my Heart, provided I may be conceal'd; as to that,

you shall be Secure? for the Nurse shall never so much as dare to Enquire about you, and you shall once or twice a Year go with me and see your Child, and see how 'tis used, and be satisfy'd that it is in good Hands, no Body knowing who you are. WHY,
do you think Mother, that when I come to see my Child, I shall be able to conceal my being the Mother of it, do you think that possible? WELL, well,

if you discover it, the Nurse shall be never the wiser; for she shall be forbid to ask any Questions about you, or to take any Notice; if she offers it she shall lose the Money which you are to be suppos'd to give her, and the Child be taken from her too.

sample.nonSpeech:
the rest I cou'd not hear, but it

sample.dialogue: what do you mean,
what in an Inn, and upon the Road! Bless us all,
sample.nonSpeech: said I , as if I had been surpriz'd,
sample.dialogue: how can you talk so! O I can talk so very well,
I came a purpose to talk so, and I'll show you that I did,
sample.nonSpeech: and with that he pulls out a great Bundle of Papers;
sample.dialogue: you fright me,
what are all these; don't be frighted, my Dear,
sample.nonSpeech: said he , and kiss'd me, this was the first time that he had been so free to call me my Dear ; then he repeated it,
sample.dialogue: don't be frighted, you shall see what it is all,
sample.nonSpeech: then he laid them all abroad;

dialogue.comment: THE GENTLEMAN SHOWS PAPERS WHICH PROVE THAT HE IS DIVORCED.

sample.dialogue: Why, Ay,
that's the Question I wanted to have you ask me;
sample.nonSpeech: so he unrolls them, and takes out a little Chagreen Case, and gives me out of it a very fine Diamond Ring; I could not refuse it, if I had a mind to do so, for he put it upon my Finger; so I made him a Curtsy, and accepted it; then he takes out another Ring,
sample.dialogue: and this,
is for another Occasion,
sample.nonSpeech: so he puts that in his Pocket.
sample.dialogue: Well, but let me see it tho',
I guess what it is, I think you are Mad: I should have been Mad if I had done less,
sample.nonSpeech: says he , and still he did not show it me, and I had a great mind to see it; so I says,
sample.dialogue: well but let me see it; hold,
first look here,
sample.nonSpeech: then he took up the Roll again, and read it, and behold! it was a License for us to be married:
sample.dialogue: Why,
are you Distracted? why you were fully satisfy'd that I would comply, and yield at first Word, or resolv'd to take no denial; the last is certainly the Case,
but you may be mistaken,
no, no,
how can you think so? I must not be denied, I can't be denied,
sample.nonSpeech: and with that he fell to Kissing me so violently, I could not get rid of him.
sample.dialogue: why you resolve not to be deny'd indeed, I think: No, no,
I must not be denyed, I won't be deny'd, I can't be deny'd: Well, well,
sample.nonSpeech: said I , and giving him a slight Kiss,
sample.dialogue: then you shan't be deny'd,

let me get up. MOLL AND THE GENTLEMAN CONTINUE.
'Tis time enough,
in the Morning, is it not? Why,
my Dear, he seem'd to scruple whether it was not some young Girl stolen from her Parents, and I assur'd him we were both of Age to command our own Consent; and that made him ask to see you; well,
do as you please;
sample.nonSpeech: so up they brings the Parson, and a merry good sort of Gentleman he was; he had been told, it seems, that we had met there by accident, that I came in the Chester Coach, and my Gentleman in his own Coach to meet me; that we were to have met last Night at Stony-Stratford , but that he could not reach so far:
sample.dialogue: Well, Sir,
every ill turn has some good in it; the Disappointment, Sir,
was yours, and the good Turn is mine, for if you had met at Stony-Stratford I had not had the Honour to Marry you: LANDLORD have you a Common-Prayer Book .
sample.nonSpeech: I started as if I had been frighted,
sample.dialogue: Lord, Sir,
what do you mean, what to marry in an Inn, and at Night too: Madam,

if you will have it be in the Church you shall; but I assure you your Marriage will be as firm here as in the Church; we are not tyed by the Canons to Marry no where but in the Church; and if you will have it in the Church it will be as publick as a Country Fair; and as for the time of Day it does not at all weigh in this Case, our Princes are married in their Chambers, and at Eight or Ten a Clock at Night.

dialogue.comment: MOLL IS A WIDOW IN LONDON: SHE HAS BECOME A THIEF AND ENTERS AN ALE-HOUSE.

sample.dialogue: d' ye call ,
sample.nonSpeech: I spoke with a melancholly Air, and said,
sample.dialogue: no Child, the Boy is gone for a Pint of Ale for me.
sample.nonSpeech: WHILE I sat here, I heard the Woman in the Bar say are they all gone in the Five, which was the Box I sat in, and the Boy said
sample.dialogue: yes ; who fetch'd the Tankard away?
I did,
that's it,
sample.nonSpeech: pointing it seems to another Tankard, which he had fetch'd from another Box by Mistake; or else it must be, that the Rogue forgot that he had not brought it in, which certainly he had not. I HEARD all this, much to my satisfaction, for I found plainly that the Tankard was not mist, and yet they concluded it was fetch'd away; so I drank my Ale, call'd to Pay, and as I went away, I said ,
sample.dialogue: take care of your Plate Child,
yes Madam, very welcome ,

dialogue.comment: MOLL GOES TO HER GOVERNESS: SHE TELLS THE GOVERNESS ABOUT HER STEALING.

sample.nonSpeech: and so told her the whole Story of the Tankard:
sample.dialogue: And have you brought it away with you my Dear,
to be sure I have,
sample.nonSpeech: says I , and I shew'd it her.
sample.dialogue: But what shall I do now,
must not I carry it again? CARRY it again!
Ay, if you are minded to be sent to Newgate for stealing it; why,
they can't be so base to stop me, when I carry it to them again? You don't know those Sort of People Child,

they'll not only carry you to Newgate , but hang you too without any regard to the honesty of returning it; or bring in an Account of all the other Tankards they have lost for you to pay for: What must I do then?
Nay,
as you have plaid the cunning part and stole it, you must e'n keep it, there's no going back now; besides Child,
Don't you want it more than they do? I wish you cou'd light of such a Bargain once a Week. MOLL AND THE GOVERNESS CONTINUE.

sample.dialogue: O, Mother!
that is a Trade I have no skill in, and if I should be taken I am undone at once;
I cou'd help you to a School-Mistress, that shall make you as dexterous as her self: ONE NIGHT A HOUSE IS ON FIRE.
sample.nonSpeech: Here she gives me a jog,
sample.dialogue: now, Child,
sample.nonSpeech: she presently gave me my Cue,
sample.dialogue: go, Child,

to the House, and run in and tell
the Lady, or any Body you see, that you come to help them, and that you came from such a Gentlewoman (that is one of her Acquaintance farther up the Street);
sample.nonSpeech: she gave me the like Cue to the next House, naming another Name that was also an Acquaintance of the Gentlewoman of the House. AWAY I went, and coming to the House I found them all in Confusion, you may be sure; I run in, and finding one of the Maids,
sample.dialogue: Lord! Sweetheart,
how came this dismal Accident? Where is your Mistress? And how does she do? Is she safe? And where are the Children? I come from Madam -- to help you;
Madam, Madam,
sample.nonSpeech: says she , screaming as loud as she cou'd yell,
sample.dialogue: here is a Gentlewoman come from Madam -- to help us :
sample.nonSpeech: The poor Woman half out of her Wits, with a Bundle under her Arm, and two little Children, comes towards me,
sample.dialogue: Lord, Madam ,
let me carry the poor Children to Madam --, she desires you to send them; she'll take care of the poor Lambs,
ay, do, for God sake ,
carry them to her; O thank her for her kindness : Have you any thing else to secure , Madam?
she will take care of it: O dear! ay,
God bless her, and thank her, take this bundle of Plate and carry it to her too; O she is a good Woman; O Lord, we are utterly ruin'd, utterly undone ;
sample.nonSpeech: and away she runs from me out of her Wits, and the Maids after her, and away comes I with the two Children and the Bundle. I WAS no sooner got into the Street, but I saw another Woman come to me,
sample.dialogue: O!
Mistress,
you will let fall the Child; come, this is a sad time, let me help you,
sample.nonSpeech: and immediately lays hold of my Bundle to carry it for me;
sample.dialogue: no,
if you will help me, take the Child by the Hand, and lead it for me but to the upper end of the Street, I'll go with you and satisfie you for your pains.
sample.nonSpeech: SHE cou'd not avoid going, after what I said, but the Creature, in short, was one of the same Business with me, and wanted nothing but the Bundle; however, she went with me to the Door, for she cou'd not help it; when we were come there I whisper'd her,
sample.dialogue: go Child ,
I understand your Trade , you may meet with Purchase enough.
sample.nonSpeech: SHE understood me and walk'd off; I thundered at the Door with the Children, and as the People were rais'd before by the noise of the Fire, I was soon let in, and I said,
sample.dialogue: is Madam awake, pray tell her Mrs. -- desires the favour of her to take the two Children in ; poor Lady, she will be undone, their House is all of a Flame ;
sample.nonSpeech: they took the Children in very civily, pitied the Family in Distress, and away came I with my Bundle; one of the Maid's ask'd me, if I was not to leave the Bundle too? I said
sample.dialogue: no, Sweetheart, 'tis to go to another place, it does not belong to them.

dialogue.comment: MOLL TALKS TO THE GOVERNESS AFTER ROBBING A DRUNKEN GENTLEMAN.

sample.dialogue: nay, Child,
the usage may, for ought I know, do more to reform him, than all the Sermons that ever he will hear in his Life,
sample.nonSpeech: and if the remainder of the Story be true, so it did. I FOUND the next Day she was wonderful inquisitive about this Gentleman; the description I had given her of him, his Dress, his Person, his Face, every thing concur'd to make her think of a Gentleman whose Character she knew, and Family too; she mus'd a while, and I going still on with the Particulars, she starts up, says she ,
sample.dialogue: I'll lay a Hundred Pound I know the Gentleman. I AM sorry you do,

for I would not have him expos'd on any account in the World; he has had Injury enough already by me, and I would
not be instrumental to do him any more: No, no
sample.nonSpeech: I was a little startled at that, and told her with an apparent concern in my Face, that by the same Rule he might find me out, and then I was undone: she return'd warmly ,
sample.dialogue: why, do you think I will betray you, Child? No, no,
not for all he is worth in the World; I have kept your Counsel in worse things than these, sure you may trust me in this:
sample.nonSpeech: So I said no more at that time.

dialogue.comment: THE GOVERNESS IS VISITED BY A FRIEND.

sample.nonSpeech: THE next Day she comes to my Governess and tells her, that Sir -- was at Home, but that he had met with a Disaster and was very ill, and there was no speaking with him;
sample.dialogue: what Disaster,
sample.nonSpeech: says my Governess hastily , as if she was surpriz'd at it?
sample.dialogue: Why,

he had been at Hampstead to Visit a Gentleman of his Acquaintance, and as he came back again he was set upon and Robb'd; and having got a little Drink too, as they suppose, the Rogues abus'd him, and he is very ill: Robb'd,
and what did they take from him; why,

they
took his Gold Watch, and his Gold Snuff-box, his fine Perriwig, and what Money he had in his Pocket, which was considerable to be sure, for Sir -- never goes without a Purse of Guineas about him. PSHAW!

I warrant you he has got drunk now and got a Whore, and she has pick'd his Pocket, and so he comes home to his Wife and tells her he has been Robb'd; that's an old sham, a thousand such tricks are put upon the poor Women every Day. FYE,

I find you don't know Sir --, why he is as Civil a Gentleman, there is not a finer Man, nor a soberer grave modester Person in the whole City; he abhors such things, there's no Body that knows him will think such a thing of him: Well, well,

that's none of my Business, if it was, I warrant I should find there was something of that kind in it; your Modest Men in common Opinion are sometimes no better than other People, only they keep a better Character, or if you please, are the better Hypocrites. No, no,
I can assure you Sir -- is no Hypocrite, he is really an honest sober Gentleman, and he has certainly been Robb'd: Nay,
it may be he has, it is no Business of mine I tell you; I only want to speak with him, my Business is of another Nature; but,
let your Business be of what nature it will, you cannot see him yet, for he is not fit to be seen, for he is very ill, and bruis'd very much: Ay,
nay then he has fallen into bad Hands to be sure;
pray where is he bruised? Why in his Head,

and one of his Hands,
and his Face, for they us'd him barbarously. Poor Gentleman,
I must wait then till he recovers,
I hope it will not be long, for I want very much to speak with him.
sample.nonSpeech: AWAY she comes to me and tells me this Story,
sample.dialogue: I have found out your fine Gentleman, and a fine Gentleman he was,
but Mercy on him, he is in a sad pickle now, I wonder what the D--l you have done to him; why you have almost kill'd him:
sample.nonSpeech: I look'd at her with disorder enough;
sample.dialogue: I kill'd him!
you must mistake the Person, I am sure I did nothing to him, he was very well when I left him,
only drunk and fast asleep; I know nothing of that,
but he is in a sad pickle now,
sample.nonSpeech: and so she told me all that her Friend had said to her:
sample.dialogue: Well then,
he fell into bad Hands after I left him, for I am sure I left him safe enough. THE GOVERNESS GOES TO SEE THE GENTLEMAN.
sample.nonSpeech: HE look'd a little angrily at first,
sample.dialogue: what Adventure?
why, Sir,
of your being Robb'd coming from Knightsbr--, Hampstead , Sir, I should say,
be not surpris'd, Sir,

that I am able to tell you every step you took that Day from the Cloyster in Smithfield , to
the Spring-Garden at Knightsbridge , and thence to the -- in the Strand , and how you were left asleep in the Coach afterwards; I say let not this surprize you, for Sir I do not come to make a Booty of you, I ask nothing of you, and I assure you the Woman that was with you knows nothing who you are, and never shall; and yet perhaps I may serve you farther still, for I did not come barely to let you know, that I was inform'd of these things, as if I wanted a Bribe to conceal them; assure your self, Sir,
that whatever you think fit to do or say to me, it shall be all a secret as it is, as much as if I were in my Grave.
sample.nonSpeech: HE was astonish'd at her Discourse, and said gravely to her,
sample.dialogue: Madam, you are a Stranger to me, but it is very unfortunate, that you should be let into the Secret of the worst action of my Life, and a thing that I am so justly asham'd of, that the only satisfaction of it to me was, that I thought it was known only to God and my own Conscience: Pray, Sir,

do not reckon the Discovery of it to me, to be any part of your Misfortune; it was a thing, I believe, you were surprised into, and perhaps the Woman us'd some Art to prompt you to it; however, you will never find any just Cause,
to repent that I came to hear of it; nor can your own Mouth be more silent in it than I have been, and ever shall be. WELL,

but let me do some Justice to the Woman too, whoever she is, I do assure you she prompted me to nothing, she rather declin'd me, it was my own Folly and Madness that brought me into it all, ay and brought her into it too; I must give her her due so far, as to what she took from me, I cou'd expect no less from her
in the condition I was in, and to this Hour I know not whether she Robb'd me or the Coachman; if she did it I forgive her, and I think all Gentlemen that do so, should be us'd in the same manner; but I am more concern'd for some other things than I am for all that she took from me.
sample.nonSpeech: MY Governess now began to come into the whole matter, and he open'd himself freely to her; first, she said to him, in answer to what he had said about me,
sample.dialogue: I am glad Sir you are so just to the Person that you were with; I assure you she is a Gentlewoman, and no Woman of the Town; and however you prevail'd with her so far as you did, I am sure 'tis not her Practise; you run a great venture indeed, Sir, but if that be any part of your Care, I am perswaded you may be perfectly easie, for I dare assure you no Man has touch'd her, before you, since her Husband, and he has been dead now almost eight Year.
sample.nonSpeech: IT appear'd that this was his Grievance, and that he was in a very great fright about it; however, when my Governess said this to him he appeared very well pleased; and said,
sample.dialogue: well, Madam, to be plain with you, if I was satisfy'd of that, I should not so much value what I lost; for as to that, the Temptation was great, and perhaps she was poor and wanted it: If she had not been poor Sir --,

I assure you she would never have yielded to you, and as her Poverty first prevailed with her to let you do as you did, so the same Poverty prevail'd with her to pay her self at last, when she saw you was in such a Condition, that if she had not done it, perhaps the next Coach-man or Chair-man might have done it. WELL,

much good may it do her; I say again, all the Gentlemen that do so, ought to be
us'd in the same manner, and then they would be cautious of themselves; I have no more concern about it, but on the score which you hinted at before, Madam:

dialogue.comment: MOLL IS ACCUSED OF STEALING IN A SHOP, AND DETAINED BY THE SHOPKEEPER.

sample.nonSpeech: the Porter said he would serve me with all his Heart;
sample.dialogue: but, Madam,
let me hear them refuse to let you go, then I may be able to speak the plainer.
sample.nonSpeech: WITH that I spoke aloud to the Master of the Shop, and said,
sample.dialogue: Sir, you know in your own Conscience that I am not the Person you look for, and that I was not in your Shop before, therefore I demand that you detain me here no longer, or tell me the reason of your stopping me;
very well,
sample.nonSpeech: said I to the Constable and to the Porter,
sample.dialogue: yes Madam ,
sample.nonSpeech: and the Constable began not to like it, and would have perswaded the Mercer to dismiss him, and let me go, since, as he said, he own'd I was not the Person;
sample.dialogue: Good Sir,
sample.nonSpeech: says the Mercer to him Tauntingly ,
sample.dialogue: are you a Justice of Peace, or a Constable? I charg'd you with her, pray do you do your Duty:
sample.nonSpeech: The Constable told him a little mov'd, but very handsomely,
sample.dialogue: I know my Duty, and what I am, Sir, I doubt you hardly know what you are doing ;
sample.nonSpeech: they had some other hard words, and in the mean time the Journey-men, impudent and unmanly to the last degree, used me barbarously, and one of them, the same that first seized upon me, pretended he would search me, and began to lay Hands on me: I spit in his Face, call'd out to the Constable, and bad him take notice of my usage;
sample.dialogue: and pray, Mr. Constable,
ask that Villain's Name,
sample.nonSpeech:
pointing to the Man; the Constable reprov'd him decently, told him that he did not know what he
did, for he knew that his Master acknowledg'd I was not the Person that was in his Shop; and, says the Constable,
sample.dialogue: I am afraid your Master is bringing himself and me too into Trouble, if this Gentlewoman comes to prove who she is, and where she was, and it appears that she is not the Woman you pretend to; Dam her,
sample.nonSpeech: says the Fellow again , with an impudent harden'd Face,
sample.dialogue: she is the Lady you may depend upon it, I'll swear she is the same Body that was in the Shop, and that I gave the pieces of Satin that is lost into her own hand, you shall hear more of it when Mr. William and Anthony, those were other Journeymen , come back, they will know her again as well as I.
sample.nonSpeech: JUST as the insolent Rogue was talking thus to the Constable, comes back Mr. William and Mr. Anthony , as he call'd them, and a great Rabble with them, bringing along with them the true Widow that I was pretended to be; and they came sweating and blowing into the Shop, and with a great deal of Triumph dragging the poor Creature in a most butcherly manner up towards their Master, who was in the back Shop, and cryed out aloud,
sample.dialogue: here's the Widow, Sir, we have catch'd her at last; what do ye mean by that,
why we have her already, there she sits,
and Mr. --
can swear this is she:
sample.nonSpeech: The other Man who they call'd Mr. Anthony replyed,
sample.dialogue: Mr. -- may say what he will, and swear what he will, but this is the Woman, and there's the Remnant of Sattin she stole, I took it out of her Cloaths with my own Hand.
sample.nonSpeech: I SAT still now, and began to take a better Heart, but smil'd and said nothing; the Master look'd Pale; the Constable turn'd about and look'd at me;
sample.dialogue: let 'em alone Mr. Constable ,
let 'em go on ;
sample.nonSpeech: the Case was plain and could not be denied, so the Constable was charg'd with the right Thief, and the Mercer told me very civily he was sorry for the mistake, and hoped I would not take it ill; that they had so many things of this nature put upon them every Day, that they cou'd not be blam'd for being very sharp in doing themselves Justice:
sample.dialogue: Not take it ill, Sir!

how can I take it well? if you had dismiss'd me when your insolent Fellow seiz'd on me in the Street, and brought me to you; and when you your self acknowledg'd I was not the Person, I would have put it by, and not taken it ill, because of the many ill things I believe you have put upon you daily; but your Treatment of me since has been unsufferable, and especially that of your Servant, I must and will have Reparation for that. MOLL RELATES THE STORY FROM THE SHOP TO HER GOVERNESS.
Why are you merry,
the Story has not so much Laughing room in it, as you imagine; I am sure I have had a great deal of Hurry and Fright too, with a Pack of ugly Rogues. Laugh ,
I laugh Child to see what a lucky Creature you are; why this Jobb will be the best Bargain to you, that ever you made in your Life, if you manage it well: I warrant you,
you shall make the Mercer pay you 500 l. for Damages, besides what you shall get of the Journeyman.

dialogue.comment: MOLL SEES HER LANCASHIRE-HUSBAND WHO IS ALSO IN PRISON FOR ROBBERY.

sample.nonSpeech: AS soon as he was gone, and I had shut the Door, I threw off my Hood, and bursting out into Tears,
sample.dialogue: my Dear ,
do you not know me ?
sample.nonSpeech: He turn'd pale and stood Speechless, like one Thunder struck, and not able to conquer the Surprize, said no more but this,
sample.dialogue: let me sit down ; MOLL AND HER LANCASHIRE HUSBAND CONTINUE.
sample.nonSpeech: but after I had given some vent to my Passion by Tears, I repeated the same Words:
sample.dialogue: MY DEAR, do you not know me ?
YES,
sample.nonSpeech: and said no more a good while. AFTER some time continuing in the Surprize, as above , he cast up his Eyes towards me and said,
sample.dialogue: How could you be so cruel ?
sample.nonSpeech: I did not readily understand what he meant; and I answer'd,
sample.dialogue: How can you call me Cruel? What have I been Cruel to you in? To come to me ,
in such a Place as this, is it not to insult me? I have not robb'd you? at least not on the Highway?
sample.nonSpeech: I PERCEIV'D by this, that he knew nothing of the miserable Circumstances I was in, and thought that having got some Intelligence of his being there, I had come to upbraid him with his leaving me; but I had too much to say to him to be affronted, and told him in few Words, that I was far from coming to Insult him, but at best I came to Condole mutually, that he would be easily satisfy'd, that I had no such View, when I should tell him that my Condition was worse than his, and that many ways : He look'd a little concern'd at the general Expression of my Condition being worse than his; but with a kind of a smile, look'd a little wildly, and said,
sample.dialogue: How can that be? when you see me Feter'd, and in Newgate , and two of my Companions Executed already; can you say your Condition is worse than Mine? COME my Dear,

we have a long peice of Work to do, if I should be to relate, or you to hear my unfortunate History; but if you are dispos'd to hear it, you will soon conclude with me that my Condition is worse than yours: How is that possible,

when I expect to be
cast for my Life the very next Sessions? Yes
'tis very possible when I shall tell you that I have been cast for my Life three Sessions ago, and am under Sentence of Death, is not my Case worse than yours?
sample.nonSpeech: THEN indeed he stood silent again, like one struck Dumb, and after a little while he starts up,
sample.dialogue: unhappy Couple!
How can this be possible?
sample.nonSpeech: I took him by the Hand,
sample.dialogue: come MY DEAR,

sit down, and let us compare our Sorrows: I am a Prisoner in this very House, and in a much worse Circumstance than you, and you will be satisfy'd I do not come to Insult you, when I tell you the particulars; MOLL TELLS HER STORY TO HER LANCASHIRE HUSBAND.
sample.nonSpeech: but when I came to the Story of little Brickill , he was surpriz'd,
sample.dialogue: and was it you my Dear ,
that gave the Check to the Mob that was at our Heels there , at Brickill : Yes
it was I indeed,
sample.nonSpeech: and then I told him the particulars which I had observ'd of him there.
sample.dialogue: Why then ,

it was you that sav'd my Life at that time , and I am glad I owe my Life to you, for I will pay the Debt to you now, and I'll deliver you from the present Condition you are in, or I will die in the attempt.
'twas no matter for that
sample.nonSpeech: he said, it was a Life worth all the World to him; a Life that had given him a new Life;
sample.dialogue: for
I was never in real Danger of being taken, but that time; till the last Minute when I was taken:
